abstract.p: Letter from Dr Jennifer L Abramson says loss of 'reflective doctoring' mentioned in May 9 is most apparent in psychiatry

block.p: Nowhere in medicine is ''the demise of reflective doctoring'' more apparent than in psychiatry. Having completed three years of my psychiatry residency, I am skilled at performing a diagnostic interview, prescribing a psychotropic medication, and (if insurance allows) providing for a brief course of psychotherapy.
Sadly, there is a diminishing emphasis on fomenting a long-term therapeutic relationship or on a more holistic approach to understanding the depths of human suffering.

Nowhere in medicine is ''the demise of reflective doctoring'' more apparent than in psychiatry. Having completed three years of my psychiatry residency, I am skilled at performing a diagnostic interview, prescribing a psychotropic medication, and (if insurance allows) providing for a brief course of psychotherapy.
Sadly, there is a diminishing emphasis on fomenting a long-term therapeutic relationship or on a more holistic approach to understanding the depths of human suffering.
It is convenient to blame these changes on H.M.O.'s and insurance companies, but we in medicine must ultimately bear responsibility and uphold a standard of practice of which we can be proud.
